result.markdown: --- output: html_document editor_options: chunk_output_type: console --- # Test ## Standards ### For displaying figures: ![](figs/unit1_data_dgp.png){width=100% fig-align="center"} ### For displaying code and even variable names `demo <- function(x)` `variable_2` ### For sizing graphs and code-generated plots * You can specify out-height or out-width as either pixels, inches, or percentages * You can specify both using different units * If you specify only one, the other should default to "auto" which keeps the figured scaled as in the original ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(pressure) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](app_test_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=3in height=100%} ::: ::: ### For code annotation ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ── ✔ dplyr 1.1.4 ✔ readr 2.1.5 ✔ forcats 1.0.0 ✔ stringr 1.5.1 ✔ ggplot2 3.5.0 ✔ tibble 3.2.1 ✔ lubridate 1.9.3 ✔ tidyr 1.3.1 ✔ purrr 1.0.2 ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() ℹ Use the conflicted package () to force all conflicts to become errors ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} d <- tibble (x = 1:5) |> # <1> glimpse() # <2> ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 5 Columns: 1 $ x 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ``` ::: ::: 1. make a df 2. glimpse a df ### For displaying color (like red questions) [this sentence is in red]{.red} This is an alternative method but more complex: I love R. [red]{.red} [yellow]{.yellow} [green]{.green} [blue]{.blue} [yellow background]{.yellowb} for better contrast ### Callouts for questions HTML: ::: {.callout-important collapse="true"} ## This is the question you want displayed? Here's the answer! This can be as long as you want. ::: RevealJS does not yet have callout collapse implemented. A workaround is to use code folding: ::: {.callout-important collapse="false"} ## If the DGP for y is a cubic function of x, what do we know about the expected bias for our three candidate model configurations in this example? ::: {.cell} ```{.html .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Show Answer"} The simple linear model will underfit the true DGP and therefore it will be biased b/c it can only represent y as a linear function of x. The two polynomial models will be generally unbiased b/c they have x represented with 20th order polynomials. LASSO will be slightly biased due to regularization but more on that in a later unit ``` ::: ::: ### Conditional Content Use divs to specify content to only appear in certain formats: ::: {.content-visible when-format="html"} Will only appear in HTML. ::: ::: {.content-visible when-format="revealjs"} Will only appear in revealJS ::: ### Links to qmd files as plaintext Normally, a link to a qmd file functions as a link to the rendered html of that file. To link to a qmd file that is to be downloaded or viewed as raw text, you must link to the raw.github user content: - cleaning EDA: [qmd](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/jjcurtin/book_iaml/main/application_assignments/unit_02/hw_unit_02_cleaning.qmd) - modeling EDA: [qmd](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/jjcurtin/book_iaml/main/application_assignments/unit_02/hw_unit_02_modeling.qmd)
